reviews.review_title: Wasted potential - "rotten at the core" - don't bother
reviews.content: **very mild spoilers**This movie is a tremendous letdown. The idea is a sound one, and I was curious to see what was made of the "found phone" trope, but sadly what could have been a halfway intelligent meditation on people's search for meaning - finding "missing pieces" of ourselves within each other - descends very quickly into cheap horror movie cliches that are never evolved beyond brief MacGuffins.Armie Hammer's performance as Will - an "average" guy who isn't especially likeable (he drink drives, tries to cheat on his girlfriend, and honestly hasn't got a single remarkable or interesting thing going for him) - is steady, especially next to an incredibly weak Dakota Johnson as his partner Carrie, with whom Will's relationship is foundering.What starts as a promising cross-section of characters - including Zazie Beetz as Alicia, 'the one that got away', and Brad William Henke as Eric, a boozy regular at the bar whose pack of unreasonably large, meatheaded friends can't keep their testosterone in check - is never fleshed out, so instead of symbolising Will's isolation and lack of fulfillment, the paper-thin people around him just feel like bad storytelling and poor adaptation on the part of screenwriter/director Babak Anvari (though admittedly I haven't read the novella Wounds is based on; I have no idea if that's any better, or just as concerned with indulgence of and apologism for its flawed protagonist).The plot - such as it is - feels like a shoddy rip pulled from the first couple of urban legends found on a Google search page, and never serves as anything more than a vehicle for Will's by-the-numbers traipse into insanity, culminating in a very dull "evil within" ending, which drowns us in CGI instead of building any true tension or showcasing the human callousness and disconnection that sits at the root of evil (as per the Joseph Conrad quote that kicks off the movie).To see a handful of reviews claiming those who didn't like this movie "didn't get it" or want "easily packaged entertainment" is a real shame, because it's a mistake to attribute anything about the panning of Wounds to anti-intellectualism. It's not that this movie is too ambiguous or artsy to understand... it's just that it's bad. Simplistically bad. Rather like The Perfection (2018), it's a movie that exists to frame a couple of set pieces and a vague concept, but it doesn't furnish the viewer with enough plot, style, or atmosphere to make that worthwhile.Wounds is boring, weak, and fundamentally both a waste of the viewer's time, and its own potential. If you're looking for more challenging spooky fare this Halloween that meditates on life, connection, and reality, try something like Boys in the Trees (2016), Jacob's Ladder (1990), or even Only Lovers Left Alive (2013), to start with.

This is not a movie for the ones who want things to be explained, it's for those who like to use their own imaginations to spin and find ways to fill in the blanks. You get some hints of the core meaning of it here and there, but you have to actually use your mind while watching this movie. Otherwise you'll just find it confusing, a waste of time, boring and that it sucks, etc etc. This one's for a rather narrow audience, and if you're not a part of that audience, you'll probably not like it at all. I happen to be part of that audience, and I love to use my imagination, so for me it was a good one.I'm not interested in seeing the monster, or having everything explained. That breaks the illusion for me, unless the story is about the monster itself and not a protagonist being confronted with said monster. I'm not intellectually insecure or lazy like that, so I prefer it when I have to work my mind while watching a movie, even though there's a charm to simpler movies as well. But this one will have you either feeling misled, insulted, bored to death, whatever of the same or like, or it will have you thinking about what actually is happening. I found the slow burn, the setting, the obviously flawed individuals in it, and the creeping mood coupled with the growing sense of dread and total doom refreshing and I loved the ending of it.Nothing is explained, unless you really pay attention to certain details and know what they mean; even so you still have to kick the imagination into gear, and that's why it has such an impact on the receptive ones. I for one think it's a very good movie in lots of ways, and as far as the horror part goes, it provided eminently exactly that. I felt very ill at ease when the credits rolled, and that was the whole point of it.If you want to watch it, then do so, but be prepared for disappointment, unless you're like the very few, like me for instance, who appreciates 'the not so wrapped up in a pretty little bow for your lazy mind's convenience'- movies. Then I think you'll like it more than you were prepared for. Watch it, or don't; you won't miss anything, or you'll miss one of the creepier movies out there.

About halfway through the movie, Armie Hammer reads a couple of lines on an internet chat forum claiming wounds can be used in a ritual to "contact higher beings" and help you become a better person.
These two lines, shown on screen for 5 seconds, are the only plot exposition in the entire movie.
Armie is a bad guy living a bad life - a borderline alcoholic, stuck in a dead end job, with a girlfriend who doesn't love him, and a female friend who he keeps trying to cheat with, but who doesn't want him. However, after being "chosen", he begins to see horrible visions all around him, which i guess are meant to signify how rotten his life has become... driven mad by this, he quits his job, breaks up with his girlfriend, and finally gets closure with the other woman... all of which seem like healthy steps toward becoming a "better person" - he just gets there in the most gross and confusing ways imaginable. He then accepts his new "better" life by embracing the creature which bursts forth from his conveniently-wounded friend, in the hope that it will "make him whole" (his girlfriend previously insults him for being an empty, hollow person, so this could be his motivation).
Are his visions the result of this existential crisis? Alcohol-fuelled mania? Some sort of curse? How & why was he "chosen" in the first place? I've done my best to interpret some semblance of meaning from this movie, but it's badly-told at best. Hammer & co are as competent on screen as you'd expect, but it feels wasted on what amounts to nothing more than a schlocky gross-out "horror" with no scares and even less plot.

reviews.review_title: A result of too many recycled ideas pushed into one script
reviews.content: I love weird horror movies that don't give away too much and leave it to the viewer to interpret. This movie probably tried to do something like that but it ended up as a disgusting mess (literally) and that's a shame, because the cast is decent and that movie could have been way better if they would have stuck with one idea and tried to make sense of it. Instead the movie takes from almost every horror movie (from the stupid demonic phone challenges movies), to Cronenberg's body-horror and also H.P Lovecraft and Franz Kafka's existential literature. Again, nothing bad in taking inspiration from others, but when you are doing it so bluntly and just putting these themes inside in order to put them there it's actually offensive.For example, Will feels rotten, small, his life is meaningless and his existence is insignificant you know, like Kafka's metamorphosis? Hence why the viewer is subjected to endless CGI cockroaches hunting the screen, and even a revolting vision of a cockroach hiding inside Will's armpit. You know, one or two of these would have been enough for the intelligent viewer to understand but noooo let's over-use this disgusting imagery and insult the viewers instead. And why exactly? Because instead of putting some effort into developing Will's character and hint toward his emptiness we will show him being a bit of a jerk to others and again, lots of roaches.And there is this weird creature of the void which can be summoned through, wounds, why? because someone googled it online? No seriously, there is nooooo background to this. How did these college kids found out about the ritual from the first place, what is this ritual? why would you even summon that creature? Does it give you anything? There is not reason behind it. No explanation why Carrie (Will's girlfriend) is hypnotized and possessed by the vortex she encountered, why don't they trust one another? Why does he even care if he basically wants this other girl. For a sec there I thought it might make sense but the movie just drops everything in the last act and we end up with Will willingly letting that whatever creature go into his open mouth while begging it to make him whole. But the movie never for once claimed that this creature will do that, or anything at all. No, I am supposed to understand that in the last 2 seconds of the movie because that's what the character is whispering in a really disgusting scene.It's such a waste and again, could have been actually an interesting movie because the concept is interesting, the actors are good and Armie is really pretty good in portraying this nice guy who is fun to be around but also pretty hallow.

I really liked this for its mood and creepy sense of sanity unravelling. Yes it has a slow pace and build up but the unnameable horror lurking beneath the surface hinted at some Lovecraftian nightmare that is too weird and strange to perceive directly. I can understand it not being a popcorn hit but this is precisely the kind of film that I enjoy for its extremely disconcerting vibe. The end sequence I will not be forgetting in a hurry. I always find that things not seen directly are scarier than the obvious, and the film does well at hinting at the horror lurking beneath the surface of reality. Definitely would appeal to fans of Lovecraft.

Pretty good example of the 'sophomore slump' here. After the excellent Under the Shadow, rich with its cultural identity, historical context and social commentary, Babak Anvari hits us with a fairly generic (though nicely cast) supernatural horror film. At times it had potential, it could have truly dived deep into a kind of gory lunacy but just when it seemed like it was about to take the plunge, we got a lame jumpscare, or some CGI insects.In my opinion it should have tried to do more from the 'body horror' angle, and less from the whole occult thing. Feels played out, hopefully his third project (whatever/whenever that may be) gets back to what he achieved with his debut, not necessarily that I think he should return to folk horror, just that he should try to touch on something more personal and original again.This could have been directed by literally anybody else and it'd be the same product.

One of those 'I really see what they tried to do there' kind of a movie that has a fascinating and fairly original premise but was executed in such a bland way. I don't mind unlike a lot of people on here that a lot was left unsaid, I don't need to be bashed over the heada by General Exposition in my Horror Movies - the more left unsaid the better IMHO. It reminded me in its intention of a combination of House of Leaves (in the uncovering of Uncanny Media, to say the least) and Angel heart (in the New Orleans setting and the unlieable Anti-Hero central character who stumbles into the center of a plot far greater than he, to which he has no understanding) which sounds great but was executed in such a dull way that it left me just wanting to read the book as I was intriqued by the premise.
In the execution, I was bored stiff by the opening 10 minute sequence set in a bar which is 'supposed to' set up the action. I say 'supposed to' because its a long pointless scene that is extremelly dull and flat and does not tell you much about what is going on a=or about to happen or much about any of the characters. The most interesting character is the protagonists ]girlfriend who is set up with an interesting character but does very little in the film, even after very strange things start to happen to her - she just comes to her senses and leaves the story once more leaving the viewer wishing we were walking out the door with her.
Would love to read the story as its a great set-up and leaves you thinking; if they chose to make a film out of this then the source material must be great - but can't find it for sale anywhere.

Seriously ... I can't believe I've just wasted an hour and half on this film!! No explanation of anything going , then it just finishes!!!! This movie was exceptional! A lot of people seemed to be complaining about the fact that the movie repeatedly subverted their expectations. Although this would usually be phrased more like 'this movie doesn't make sense'. But the terror in the movie is literally fueled by this confusion. Our confusion is also aided by the fact that the story only follows through the perspective of someone that is going crazy, and so naturally we start to associate ourselves with our only point of view. Several situations indirectly suggest the presence of loop-structures, which in part serve the purpose of marvel at the creators creative planning and self-awareness. Although loop-structures can also be associated with nonsense by a surface level evaluation. A large portion of the entertainment is inevitably fueled by our intellectual curiosity, as we reflect on what expectations the creators tried to provoke, in order to inevitably subvert them. Since this reflecting requires us to hypothesize the intentions of someone trying to confuse us, there is a built in loop structure within the action of this reflection, and which inherently makes the analysis difficult. In turn we obtain significant confusion resulting in an intellectual state of terror.

reviews.review_title: Yet another high budget, Netflix mess.
reviews.content: I was slightly more optimistic with this film than the other Netflix originals in circulation. But a short while into the film (about 20 mins) I realised that it was going to be just another Netflix original.The actors in the mix of the film provide a glimpse of hope but that hope is quickly turned into dread when the film gets underway. Hammers performance is perhaps the best of the bunch - and believe me that is not hard at all. Johnson looks like she was forced to star and Zazie Beetz is under used in the overall movie.The only positive I can draw from this film is the standard of effects. Netflix being the streaming giant that it is, has money to put into films like Wounds. The films effects are good (not great). They are fairly realistic and show a slight glimpse of hope for the future Netflix horrors.
Watched it because of the cast. So awful it was painful to watch

reviews.review_title: Wouldn't even recommend it to dead people.
reviews.content: So... one day I got up and the sun was super high up in the sky, it was so pretty. The next day I got up and the sun was a little higher than the previous, it was even prettier. Then the next day amazingly enough, as I got up the sun was even a little higher than the previous day, it was even a little prettier. A day after, I got up and the sun was higher only a little bit compared to the previous day, but it was still higher than the prvious day, it was even a little prettier. The following day, I got up and the sun was now almost highest it could be, and it was almost as pretty as it could be. Then the next day, the sun was at its highest, and it was the prettiest.... Still better story than the movie.

Started off with so much promise but was ruined in the last third of the film i shall not bother discussing the drivel that is the plot of the film, by now we should be used to the quality that we watch on Netflix, however i will say for those that claim this is anything but a bad film, you must identify as gender fluid because its pretentious, to clever for its own good and well lets just say it, wrong.
I've watched a lot of bad movies in my time but this has made number one. The movie was incredibly slow, made very little sense and was mind numbingly boring.

Wowee, where to begin with this thing? Well, to start with, I really don't mind ambiguity in a film. I often really like it when the audience is given the opportunity to interpret sometimes vague events in their own way, but in the case of Wounds, it's pretty clear that the ambiguity on display here is a product of nobody involved having a clear idea of what in the hell this film was supposed to be. It's as though it was made by several people who all weren't taking to each other at any time during its making.
Barely anything in this film makes a lick of sense, and there's little motivation to try and make any sense of it, because the characters are all such one dimensional bores, that you soon stop caring about anything that might be happening to them.
What's so frustrating, is that you can see that if this wasn't such a confused mess, there actually could have been a decent film here.

Netflix: I want my 90 minutes back. How can a director mix some great actors with less than average ones to turn out a movie so frustratingly senseless? People, you have been warned....spend your valuable time elsewhere.
Absolute flop. Worst ending ever. Had such potential but it sucked.

reviews.review_title: 1.5 hours wasted which I'll never get back
reviews.content:
This movie is complete and utter garbage. I was expecting a nice mysterious horror movie. What I got instead was one and a half hour of filler trash complete of course with horrifically bad acting. First of all, the "Ritual" part of the movie doesn't get developed whatsoever. Literally all you get to see that it's supposed to summon an evil being or something (At this point I was looking at my phone because I was so bored) and the rest is just cockroaches and visions of the "tunnel" with random jumpscares, because how else are they gonna scare the audience?
So, the horror part of the movie is undeveloped garbage. What does the other part of the movie consist of, you might be asking?
Well the rest is basically Armie Hammer's character Will (who was TERRIBLE in this movie by the way) just moseying around at the bar speaking uninteresting and boredom inducing dialogue to random background characters. Occasionally, some "horror" happens which you guessed it, is not scary AT ALL. The film ended with a cop out ending where you find out nothing about the ritual. Nice!
All in all do not watch this film under any circumstances. This is likely the worst Netflix movie that I've ever seen. Go watch In the tall grass instead.
The person who inflicted this movie on humanity should be punshed.

reviews.review_title: The entire movie is a Build up with no climax or ending

However the whole movie hangs onto a build up with no progress, no deaths, a very vague explanation, and no scares whatsoever. The movie leaves you sitting there waiting for something happens, but nothing ever does. Only within the last minute of the film is there any "climax" and even then its left unexplained.The actors are good and the idea has potential, but this definitely failed to deliver.
Hate the main character, dumb, smiley, stupid straight jerk, don't pity him at all in any moments, bad script and useless characters created make this movie really bad, 100% disappointed.

I was hooked up to that point. Then, everything seemed to fast forward to the ending and this is where things got a bit uglier. This is not to say this movie is bad or anything because I think it was well done overall, it's just that it's lacking of a good ending and more development on the interesting parts. I still gave it a 6/10 as it was entertaining but it could have got so much more with a great ending. Still, good job!

reviews.review_title: In an attempt to be clever, the filmmaker forgets their own message.

This film has a run time of 95 mins but due to its glacial pacing and sheer lack of energy from everyone and everything, it feels like 3 hour film.A lost phone and some cockroaches are supposed to serve as macguffins but again, nothing is explained and the viewer is left with an ambiguous, anticlimactic ending. As Shakespeare once said "All sound and fury, signifying nothing..."

Are people that used to watching garbage horror movies that any piece of video with some sound effects and random scenes thrown in there take from 7 to 10 out of 10? While bashing people who actually EXPLAIN why they rated it low! Here is my piece of mind! I just finished watching this movie and I am horribly disappointed. I feel like I didn't even watch it, nothing meaningful stayed with me. I am a HUGE fan of horror story telling, I absolutely love Stephen King's books and have a library full of them, I love a good movie, discover a good story, after all that is why we're watching or reading a story! "Wounds" on the other hand has no story. I had no idea what Wounds was about when I pressed play and still have no idea what it is all about when it ended. By tomorrow I will not even remember I watched it lol. At least "The Nun" and other titles mentioned in some high ratings to attempt a comparison have an actual story and an actual PLOT, the audience know what the story is about all the way to the end. I would watch those twice rather than watch this meaningless movie again. Hey some people have really low standards and get happy with whatever is fed to them, good for them, won't judge.On the other hand I want something more, I want to live the story, feel the character's emotions, guide me through their world just as they see it. I want to see DEVELOPMENT in the story, I want to sit at the edge of my seat and be kept on my toes. That's why I rate it 1 out of 10. This movie delivered nothing to me.

This was one of those movies that was a complete waste of an hour and a half of my life I'll never get back LOL. One of the worst movies I've seen in a while. TOTALLY pointless. As many other reviewers have pointed out, nothing in the plotline or movie make any sense at all -- and not in an intentional, "this is complex and hidden clues and you have to figure it out" way, but in a completely disjointed, throw a bunch of unrelated creepy stuff in with absolutely no story that ties it together way.

Soooo many questions that apparently no one involved, from the writers to producers to directors to cast, thought to ask or answer. What did the college kids at the beginning have to do with anything? What's the deal with the tunnel and the eye? What is the entire reason/story behind the happenings?

To top it off, the main character is intensely dislikable with apparently no redeeming qualities at all. I spent the entire movie just WISHING whatever the evil presence was would just end his ass already.

And Dakota Johnson....sigh. How did she get to be cast in ANYTHING as an actress? Her performance/role in this film is just as it has been in every other film I've seen with her in it - a bland cutout cardboard person with one expression who adds nothing to the movie at all. 

Do yourself a big favor and avoid this movie like the plague. Wish I'd read a few reviews before mindlessly selecting it ha ha.

If there had been other writers perhaps this could've been good but I don't recommend watching it. It's not Dakota Johnson's best work either, she's horrible in this.

I find it hard to believe that anyone involved in the making of this film cared at all except for whoever animated all those cockroaches. (Seriously, so many cockroaches. Why?)

An erratic, poorly paced, poorly plotted movie that randomly throws jump scares, out-of-shot thriller elements, ick-factor, mystery, techno-terror and muddled arcane mumbo-jumbo at the audience with no unifying motive. Apparent allusions to TS Eliot in content, theme and structure do not hold together with sufficient conviction to make it a homage, nor an exploration of modernist alienation and angst transported to the early 21st century. Beyond some isolated thrills, some good lighting and the occasional moody shot, this hodgepodge of horror tropes succeeds neither intellectually nor viscerally. It is difficult to comment on the acting, since the script gives the actors almost no scope or depth, and without the effect of convincingly echoing the key 'Hollow Men' theme of the film.

Wounds (1 out of 5 stars). Wounds is a psychological horror film that is a complete waste of time. The only horror thing about the movie is the complete boredom. The performances are tedious. The direction and script is stupid and dull. The film lacks scares and thrills. It feels like a terrible version of The Ring movie. The plot is boring. It follows a bartender played by Armie Hammer. After a random fight happens in his bar. Some teenager left their phone which he picks up. He looks at the pictures which has a disturbing dead person. From there on, his life is spiraling down when a strange car has been following him. His obsession over his friend played by Zazie Beetz. While his girlfriend played by Dakota Johnson is distant. And everywhere he goes there seems to be more cockroaches running around. The plot plays around with the concept which it barely explains in the movie about a teenager opening up a portal. Where wounds is the opening to another world. Nothing more is explained besides that. You spend the rest of the movie watching Armie Hammer's character going insane with his drinking problem. Mood swings. And obsession with his friend. The direction is boring. The characters make stupid decision. Such as right when the character brings home another persons phone. Which he sees a red flag text message. It takes him forever to get it to the police station. By the time he does, he loses the phone. Armie Hammer, Zazie Beetz, and Dakota Johnson are all great. But there roles and characters in this film are a waste. The characters are flat and dull. The film lacks in scares and thrills. Besides a disturbing ending which leaves you asking what did you just watch. Kind of a reaction. Overall, Wounds is one of the worst films of this year. It is boring. It is stupid. The direction and story is so tedious. It makes it hard trying to sit through it.

This is what happens when filmmakers are more fascinated by imagery and concept but don't know how to couch them in a story. Armie Hammer is Will, a bartender in a New Orleans bar who witnesses a fight break out one night while some college kids are in the bar (seemingly unrelated). The kids leave behind one of their phones, which contains disturbing images. All the while, his girlfriend Carrie, played by Dakota Johnson, seems to be studying occult Gnosticism, which seems to be related to what the college kids are involved in. If you're looking for any kind of payoff in this film, you're going to be sorely disappointed. Literally, this film has no payoff. It’s more just a bunch of stuff that happens and then, BAM!, end credits. There are times that it seems like it’s going somewhere. In fact, it felt like there should have been much more interrelated stuff between different parts of the movie, such as Claire’s professor, Steve, being more developed. In fact, I definitely get the impression that this was supposed to be the case, but that it either ended up on the cutting room floor or remained concept-only. It’s possible that this happens in “The Visible Filth,” the short novel on which this movie is based, but since I haven’t read it I can’t comment on it. The film we get is not a good film, either. The acting alternates between melodramatic and completely emotionless with no inbetween. Seriously, Brad William Henke is so over-the-top, he makes Jeremy Irons look like he was on Xanax during the “Dungeons & Dragons” movie. Dakota Johnson just sleepwalks through her entire role. Armie Hammer feels like he tries a little too hard to be the everyman. The only actor that seemed believable with genuine subtlety in their role is Zazie Beetz, but her character is pretty much superfluous to the proceedings. Her character could have been cut with little to no change to the plot. What’s so terrible about this film, though, is the sheer frustration factor. It’s a great idea. I would have loved to see more and have the movie cleaned up to be more cohesive and have an actual payoff. But we’re denied all of this. I love the concept of basing a film around occult Gnosticism. However, it’s set in such a poor movie that by the end, I found myself wringing my hands less out of fear or feelings of bugs crawling on you (which you might get) and more out of frustration for failure to realize its potential and seeing very easily how it could have been saved. When you’re doing the filmmakers work for them, they’ve got a problem.

The power of suggestion is strong, and the ending leaves you in a cliffhanger. If you need a horror villain that chases you with cheap jump scares, you’ll hate it. If not this is definitely worth your time.
